Sentence: The Inspector turns to Gerald and asks if he (Inspector) knows someone named Daisy Renton
When all but Sheila and Gerald leave the room, Sheila accuses Gerald of having had an affair with Daisy Renton the previous summer
The Inspector questions Gerald about Daisy Renton, and Gerald admits to the affair in front of Sheila and her (Sheila) parents, Arthur and Sybil
Gerald is embarrassed by his (Gerald) indiscretion, but insists his (Gerald) concern for Daisy was authentic
The Inspector tells them that the girl Sybil turned away was Eva Smith, or, as Gerald knew her (Sybil), Daisy Renton
The Inspector demonstrates that each member of the Birling family, and Gerald, has played a part in Eva/Daisy's suicide, and that all should consider themselves guilty

Gerald, however, notes that no family member saw the picture of Eva/Daisy at the same time, and that the Inspector might have conflated the family's stories by offering pictures of different women, and changing the names from Eva Smith to Daisy Renton
